events.comment:
If you want to try this example:
- Create an app on your Google Play Console or Apple App Store Connect account.
- Update the package name in the project properties.
- Export the game and upload it in a testing track.
- Ensure you've registered the items with the same IDs as entered below (see step 1).

This example implements a very basic persist of the purchases to a local storage.
If you want something more secure, you can implement a backend and a database.

Step 1. Register all products that should be available in the store. The internal ID can be found on your store's developer console. Make sure they match.
Note: it can take a few hours for products to be accessible in the app after creating them in you store's developer console.
Step 2. After registering all products finalize the registration

Step 3. If you have a storage set up (here localStorage for simplicity) load the rewards the user has received in to variables to refresh the UI.
It is recommended to use a proper backend and a Database to save this information as a local storage is easily hackable and is not able to know when a subscription is canceled for instance.

Step 4. Listen to the "approved" event for products being purchased, saving this information in a variable.

This step must be done as soon as possible, as events can be triggered as soon as the app is launched.
If done outside of "beginning of scene" condition, ensure you use a "trigger once", to avoid registering multiple watchers for the same event.

By default, when a product is purchased on an app store, it goes into an "approved" state first.
The app is responsible for receiving this event, giving the reward to the player, save the information that the reward has been given (in a database for instance), then notify the store that the transaction can be considered "finished".
If the transaction is not marked as finished, then the money will be refunded to the player, considering they did not get the reward.

Note:
- consumables, once marked as finished, will not trigger any new event. The store considers that you have handled it.
- non consumables & subscriptions, will never go into a "finished" state. This is to allow verifying if the product purchase is still valid when you launch the app later on.
It means that:
- for consumables, the "approved" event will be triggered only once if you mark the purchase as delivered properly.
- for non consumables & subscriptions, the "approved" event will be triggered on every launch of the app, or every resume. You need to ensure that the code listening to this event can be run multiple times and end up with the same outcome (ex: if a subscription already exists, it does not create a new one, just confirm it exists)
Step 5. Wait for the store to fully load to do actions on products

Step 6. Load product data

Using a Trigger once allows getting the data only once, but you can remove it if you want to synchronise the product info in real time (to the cost of performance)

Step 7. Use the product data to show information to the player, like the price, name...
See https://github.com/j3k0/cordova-plugin-purchase/blob/master/api/classes/CdvPurchase.Product.md for more info on product structure
Step 8. Initiate a purchase of the product on user request

Step 9. Once a boolean of payment goes to true, it means the payment has been approved.
As described in Step 4, this can happen when a purchase is completed, OR when the app is launched for a product that cannot be marked as finished (subscriptions & non consumables)

Multiple things must be done :
- Switch back the boolean to false, allowing a new purchase to be made, and the boolean to go back to true if needed.
- Save this information in a storage somewhere. This example use local storage for the sake of simplicity. In order for your player to see their reward again the next time they launch your app, you need to store this somewhere, and not rely on what the app store knows about the player. For example, if a level is unlocked, or a subscription purchased, you can save in localStorage that this level is now unlocked (easily hackable) or send this information to an API with a Database to retrieve it next time they launch the app. Same for subscriptions or consumables.
- Mark purchase as delivered. This ensures the money is not refunded to the player.

Use with trigger once to avoid giving multiple rewards whilst the boolean is true.

Step 10. Refresh the UI accordingly.
Now that you've saved this information in a storage, display to the user the rewards they got.
This step has 2 uses:
- Showing the user what they own when they launch the app, if the variables are correctly rehydrated from the storage
- Showing the user what they just bought, because the variables were correctly updated

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: InAppPurchase
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add products to buy directly in your game ("In-App Purchase"), for games published on Android or iOS.
description: > To set up In App Purchase, you'll need a developer account on Google Play Console or Apple App Store Connect. You will also need **real phones/devices** to test IAP, because emulators are not supported.
It's highly recommended to **read the [help page](https://wiki.gdevelop.io/gdevelop5/extensions/in-app-purchase) to begin**.
>  In-App Purchase **will only work after you exported your game and uploaded it to Google Play Console or Apple App Store Connect**, at least in a testing track.
The general worflow is the following:
- Register your products on the Google Play Console or App Store Connect,
- In your game, register the same products using the action *"Register a Product"*,
- Call the action to finalize the store registration,
- Register a variable that will be updated when an product purchase is approved (and other variables for when other things happen),
- Wait for "the store is ready" condition to be true,
- Get the products data to know what to display (in particular the *price* of each product),
- Display the price and available products in your game,
- When the player clicks on a product, use the action to order it,
- If the purchase is approved (the variable you set up is set to true), give the user what they bought

eventsFunctions.description:
Register a Product of your store. This is required to do for all products you want to display or order from the app. 

Make sure you register them all and finalize registration before ordering a product.
eventsFunctions.name: RegisterItem

parameters.description: The internal ID of the product
parameters.longDescription: Use the ID of the product you entered on the IAP provider (Google play, Apple store...)
parameters.name: id

parameters.description: Which platform you're registering the product to
parameters.name: platform

eventsFunctions.description: Finalize store registration. Do this after registering every product and before ordering or getting information about a product.
eventsFunctions.name: FinalizeRegistration

eventsFunctions.description:
Opens the purchase menu to let the user buy a product.

Ensure you use the condition to check if the store is ready and that the product ID has been registered and finalized before calling this action.
eventsFunctions.name: OrderItem

parameters.description: The id of the product to buy
parameters.name: id

eventsFunctions.description:
Get all the data about a product from the IAP provider and store it into a structure variable.
Check [this page](https://github.com/j3k0/cordova-plugin-purchase/blob/master/api/classes/CdvPurchase.Product.md) for the exhaustive list of what can be retrieved from the product.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Load product data in a variable
eventsFunctions.name: GetProduct
eventsFunctions.sentence: Store data of _PARAM1_ in scene variable named _PARAM2_

parameters.description: The id or alias of the product to get info about
parameters.name: id

parameters.description: The name of the scene variable to store the product data in
parameters.longDescription: The variable will be a structure, see [this page](https://github.com/j3k0/cordova-plugin-purchase/blob/master/api/classes/CdvPurchase.Product.md) to know what child variables are accessible.
parameters.name: variableName

eventsFunctions.description:
When an event is triggered for a product (approved or finished), this sets a scene variable to true. 
You can then compare the value of the variable in a condition, and have actions launched to react to the changes.
Use with Trigger Once to avoid registering multiple watchers unnecessarily.

Approved is triggered after the purchase is complete.
Finished is triggered after you have marked the purchased as delivered (less useful).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Update a variable when a product event is triggered
eventsFunctions.name: WatchItemEvent
eventsFunctions.sentence: Watch the event _PARAM3_ for product _PARAM1_ and set scene variable named _PARAM2_ to true when it happens

inlineCode: // If the product being watched is in the list of products in the transaction, save into a variable.
// If this action is watching the approved event, register a callback when a transaction is approved.
// If this action is watching the finished event, register a callback when a transaction is finished.

parameters.description: The id of the product to watch
parameters.name: id

parameters.description: The name of the scene variable to set to "true" when the event happens
parameters.name: variableName

eventsFunctions.description: Mark a purchase as delivered, after you delivered the rewards the user has paid for and saved it somewhere. If you don't do so, the user will get the money refunded as the purchase will be considered as incomplete, with the rewards not given.
eventsFunctions.name: FinalizePurchase

inlineCode: // Check current transactions, and validate latest one with this product id.
// Mark this transaction as finished, for the store to consider the product as given to the user.
// Return early as we assume transactions are finished one by one.

parameters.description: The id or alias of the product to finalize
parameters.name: id

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers after finalizing the registration. Products can then be retrieved and purchased (you can get data of a product like the price, you can use the action to order a product...).
eventsFunctions.name: StoreReady

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: A button that can be used for menus and most labelled buttons of a game. The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

changelog.breaking: - Buttons now use "variants", allowing easy swapping of their visual aspect. You will have to make some adjustments to existing buttons in your project. Follow this [migration documentation](https://wiki.gdevelop.io/gdevelop5/objects/custom-objects-prefab-template/migrate-to-variants/) to do these changes.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the events are running for the editor.
eventsFunctions.name: IsInGameEdition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Events are running for the editor

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.description: Reset the state of the button.
eventsFunctions.name: ResetState

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is not used.
eventsFunctions.name: IsIdle

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button was just clicked.
eventsFunctions.name: IsClicked

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the cursor is hovered over the button.
eventsFunctions.name: IsHovered

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is either hovered or pressed but not hovered.
eventsFunctions.name: IsFocused

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressed

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed outside with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressedOutside

eventsFunctions.description: the touch id that is using the button or 0 if none.
eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsBasedObjects.description: A button that can be customized.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.
